title: Single slit - fringes - beamradius r - slitwidth w

content.question: The figure shows a setup with a laser that shines light of wavelength <math alttext="lambda" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>λ</mi></math> onto a card with a narrow vertical slit of width <math alttext="w" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>w</mi></math>. The laser beam illuminates a circle of radius <math alttext="r" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi></math> on the card, where <math alttext="r is greater than w" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>r</mi><mo>></mo><mi>w</mi></math>. A viewing screen located a distance <math alttext="uppercase D" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>D</mi></math> from the card shows the resulting diffraction pattern. In the diffraction pattern, <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math> is the center-to-center distance between the two dark fringes that are adjacent to the central bright fringe. Which of the following approximates the distance <math alttext="d" display="inline" overflow="scroll"><mi>d</mi></math>? Assume that small-angle approximations are valid for the fringes shown in the diffraction pattern.
